    implicit none

    integer :: i, u

( ( str(u)(i:i) == str(u)(i+1:i+1) ) .and. ( ( str(u+1)(i:i) == str(u)(i:i) ) .or. ( str(u+1)(i+1:i+1) == str(u)(i:i) ) ) )

Yes, that's correct. Because the .and. is between the first part and the parenthetical ( B .or. C ). So that's correct.

So the first part is (A .and. (B .or. C)), then OR with (D .and. (E .or. F)).

So in Fortran, the condition should be written as:

( ( (A .and. (B .or. C)) ) .or. ( (D .and. (E .or. F)) ) )

So the Fortran code's condition should be:

if ( ( ( (str(u)(i:i) == str(u)(i+1:i+1)) .and. ( (str(u+1)(i:i) == str(u)(i:i)) .or. (str(u+1)(i+1:i+1) == str(u)(i:i)) ) ) .or. &
       ( (str(u+1)(i:i) == str(u+1)(i+1:i+1)) .and. ( (str(u)(i:i) == str(u+1)(i:i)) .or. (str(u)(i+1:i+1) == str(u+1)(i:i)) ) ) ) then

Yes, that's correct. So the code in the previous example has the correct condition.

Another thing: in Fortran, when comparing substrings, it's necessary to use the correct syntax. For example, str(u)(i:i) gives the i-th character of the u-th string. Each string is of length 4, so i can be from 1 to 4.

In the loops, u runs from 1 to 3 (since u+1 must be <=4), and i runs from 1 to 3 (since i+1 <=4). So the loops are correct.
